rrhttps://rr-project.org

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Code is the primary source of documentation, so it should be clear and readable.
Splitting a regular expression into pieces to make it readable.
An example of crappy code.

X.T: Reducing Incidental Complexity in Our Code and in Our Teaching

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some thoughts about the fact that the code we write should be simpler.
Gradually replacing a component largely used in an application by hiding it behind an abstraction layer before replacing it.
Source code files should have a maximum allowed number of lines.
Imposing clean commits results into doing less cleanup.
About the flexibility of data structures which are a composite of lists and hashmaps.

X.T: ITT 2016 - Kevlin Henney - Seven Ineffective Coding Habits of Many Programmers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Miscellaneous thoughts about naming, code layout, encapsulation, getters/setters, tests…
Some strongly-worded miscellaneous opinions about best practices and useless managers.
Thinking about legacy code, the one we inherit and the one we leave.
A description of technical debt, but the subject is much too simplified.
Martin explains that self-encapsulation, according to him, has little interest except in some particular cases.

X.T: Code Health: Reduce Nesting, Reduce Complexity

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.
It is better to use classes rather than raw primitives.

X.T: A Common Mistake When Caching Nullable Values
X.ST: It looks like there's a bug with the way Eclipse implemented modularity support. Let's see what happens when you try to cache nullable values in a non-modular project.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The problem of caching the null value.
A meaningless mixture of Diophantine equations, Hilbert’s Entscheidungsproblem, and workload estimation.
Allowing for some slight mess in the code is helpful.

X.T: Conditions Are Power-Law Distributed: An Example

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Vincent Jugé améliore l’algorithme au cœur de Python, Java et Android
X.ST: En modifiant seulement quatre lignes de code, Vincent Jugé du LIGM surpasse les performances de l’algorithme de tri de référence : Timsort. Il présente sa nouvelle version, Adaptative Shivers Sort, lors de la conférence SODA20 à Salt Lake City, dans l’espoir de remplacer le vénérable algorithme.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Why Minecraft is a Technical Feat | Explaining the Engineering Behind an Indie Icon

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title is true, but this video contains some errors or dubious claims.
A basic explanation of function currying.

X.T: Branchless Programming: Why "If" is Sloowww... and what we can do about it!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to branchless programming, something that almost no developer should use.

X.T: Fortunately, I don't squash my commits
X.ST: The story of a bug, and how I addressed it.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.
The title is very misleading, this is only about using Haskell’s QuickCheck on a very simple example.

X.T: Brute Forcing The Countdown Numbers Game - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: How NOT to Sample Audio! - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Rebuilding a voice record from a snapshot of a wave representation.
Some of the most complex x86/64 instructions.
A short history of V8, Electron, Node, VS Code… with some incorrect statements.

X.T: Coding Adventure: Ant and Slime Simulations

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all, the results are spectacular.

X.ST: Prerequisite capabilities for successful platform strategies

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice for building and exploiting internal developer tools.

X.T: WCF #5: A Most Elegant Data Structure
X.ST: A data structure from the 1960’s is still pretty cool today.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A classical description of doubly-linked list.
The description of a program that solves a kind of simple maze and draws a kind of lightning.

X.T: The Dumbest Way To Solve A Maze - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same with particles moving randomly.

X.T: Random Numbers with LFSR (Linear Feedback Shift Register) - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Code Health: Now You're Thinking With Functions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The basic: using higher-order functions.

X.ST: Regression Testing and the Saff Squeeze

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Digging out a bug in a failing test by recursively diving in the subroutines, inlining them, and removing code not related to the bug.

X.T: The “dark yellow problem” in design system color palettes

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.ST: These commercial and open-source tools will scan code and create software bills of materials automatically.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some little information about SBOM and a list of such tools.
This presentation is unclear: this is more a domain-specific language than model-driven engineering.

X.T: Cloud Development Environments Tame Complexity By Reducing State

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GitPod may be the solution to kill the cost of keeping a development environment working.

X.T: Low-code/no-code platforms: The 10% trap and the limits of abstractions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The (few) pros and the (many) cons of low-code and no-code tools.
The very basics of memory management.

X.T: Optimisation du problème du voyageur de commerce par du Machine Learning

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using K-means as a heuristic to the Traveling Salesman Problem.

X.T: 14 Ideas for Fun Python Free Time Projects

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some ideas of programs, if someone has no idea about a toy project to improve his/her development knowledge.
The very basics of state machines (Deterministic Finite Automata).
A presentation of Nondeterministic Finite Automata.

X.T: DevOps is Dead? Au fait, c’est quoi le DevOps? Et pourquoi faut-il le sécuriser? (Fred SIMON)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: No information, some biased arguments, and some wrong facts.
When you understand how numbers are represented (n is encoded as n characters "1"), you understand it is just a clever way to exploit regexps.

X.T: How a year-long LeetCode habit upped my professional game

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author describes the benefits she gets by daily practising on LeetCode.
An interesting algorithmic challenge, but MikePound’s first steps are not going far.
A poorly prepared presentation of eBPF.
Code using a double negation is difficult to understand.

X.T: Unlocking Clean Code: 20 Architectural Tips for Every Developer
X.ST: Discover 20 key architectural tips for robust software. Embrace Clean Architecture for developers seeking efficient and adaptable code.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good and classical list of coding best practices, but these ones are shortly described.
The classical problem of the possible overflow when computing the middle between two numbers.
Using a binary search to find the commit that introduced a bug.

X.T: Navigating Through Programming's Greatest Mistakes • Mark Rendle & Hannes Lowette

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some random thoughts about software development.
A good overview of the current implementation of multithreading at the CPU level: CMP, CMT, FMT, SMT…

X.T: Near-Optimal Parallel Join Processing in MapReduce

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
A very technical presentation of an algorithm to implement join models in a MapReduce framework (see also this paperhttps://www.khoury.northeastern.edu/home/mirek/papers/2011-SIGMOD-ParallelJoins.pdf
enPDF).

The authors explain that sequential consistency should be maintained instead of the current memory model of C, C++ and Java. This would simplify developers life while the performance loss would be acceptable.

X.T: Four Solutions to a Trivial Problem - Guy Steele Jr.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to parallelise the resolution of the volume of water held in a histogram, and some manifesto on the fact we must change our coding paradigms to be able to use parallelisation.
A list of miscellaneous good coding practices.
Run test locally, debugging mobile apps, proper logging, monitoring, testing small parts.
About the build and test environment: fast build and tests, presubmit queues, easy reverts, performance tests.
A description of the Internet-distributed PostgreSQL build farm. The article probably dives too much in some details, but it nevertheless gives a good idea of the whole mechanism.
A presentation of BuildMaster, the author describes the Software Delivery Process model, but there is no real description of the software features.
The reasons why builds must always be green.
An introduction to Gulp and a comparison with Grunt.

X.T: CI/CD Tools Comparison: Jenkins, TeamCity, Bamboo, Travis CI, and More

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short comparison of Jenkins, TeamCity, Bamboo, Travis CI, CircleCI, and CodeShip.
Jenkins next LTS will require Java 11.
A long list of CI/CD platforms, but the descriptions are poorly written.

X.T: Improve Your Build Process with Ant

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to Ant, but I think that this article is not very clear.
An introduction to gulp with simple examples: less, sass, minification and watching file updates.

X.T: Tools for Continuous Integration at Google Scale

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Google’s CI infrastructure.

X.T: Building Software at Google Scale Tech Talk

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A more detailed and updated description of Google build environment.

X.T: Tools for Continuous Integration at Google Scale

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Google’s infrastructure which uses dependency analysis to run only the impacted tests. But the whole required computation increases in a non-sustainable way…

X.T: Building Software at Google Scale: Bazel

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A marketing presentation of Bazel, Google’s build system.

X.T: Travis CI flaw exposed secrets of thousands of open source projects
X.ST: Developers furious at Travis CI's "insanely embarrassing 'security bulletin.'"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all: Travis CI screwed up and failed to report its mistake.

This article gives some general advice (use uint_least16_t/int_fast16_t/…, avoid strcat, use alloca…) and explains some useful gcc (computed gotos, __stdcall__, _builtin_constant_p…) and glibc (mempcpy, rawmemchr…) features.

X.T: Application Optimization on Linux Tutorial Material

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After a presentation of gprof, sprof, gcov and memprof, the author proposes an exercise to optimise a sample program. A paragraph contains some material of the previous article.

X.T: We have it easy, but do we have it right?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very good proof that performance evaluation is very difficult: very minor changes in the environment or in the executable have a large impact on the measured performance.

X.T: The Parallel Revolution Has Started: Are You Part of the Solution or Part of the Problem?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Random thoughts on parallelism: why CPUs are now multi-core? why software will have to effectively exploit parallelism? possible killer apps requiring yet further CPU performance improvements, autotunners, a simple performance model…

X.T: Using inline assembly with IBM XL C/C++ compiler for Linux on z Systems, Part 2
X.ST: An analysis based on the computation of Fibonacci sequence

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A performance analysis of several Fibonacci implementations.

X.T: Performance Engineering on Hard Mode with Andrew Hunter

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to analyse the performance of a trading system: profilers, OCaml…

X.T: Diagnosing Java code: Assertions and temporal logic in Java programming
X.ST: Introduce temporal logic to assertions to supplement testing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author introduces the idea of temporal logic: assertions taking into account the execution sequence into account ("always", "sometime", "until" and "next").

X.T: Diagnosing Java code: Using temporal logic with bug patterns
X.ST: Preventing common bugs with temporal logic assertions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some samples of how to use temporal logic, but most of them could be verified with standard assertions (i.e. "always" is the same as defining an invariant). It would be more convincing to choose more tricky bugs, but maybe the article would have been too complex…

X.ST: Augment your testing framework with Shouldly for improved test code readability and better test failure messages.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another C# assertion library.

X.T: Building bug-free O-O software: An Introduction to Design by Contract

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of design by contract.

X.T: Contracts: From Analysis to C++ Implementation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors describe how they automatically transfer the assertions from a Python prototype to the C++ implementation.

X.T: Using Design by Contract in C

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to Design by Contract for C.
A numerical analysis of the ROI of code reviews.

X.T: Single Committer Software Development - Introducing single committer and peer code review into your development process

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This article is more about the code review process in some Open Source projects (they give the example of the participation to Wine) than about the fact that the code integration is centralised by a single person.

X.T: Part of Your Complete Breakfast - Code Review is a Source of Essential Vitamins and Minerals

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Nothing new here, but this is still a good argumentation for performing code reviews. A checklist is also provided.

X.T: Your code sucks, and I hate you
X.ST: The Social Dynamics of Code Reviews

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some evangelism for doing code reviews and some advice on how to perform them.

X.T: Are you using a toolset in your code review?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some good advice, but it would be better if it would detail further how to actually perform the code review.

X.T: Agile Techniques: When and How to Conduct a Code Review
X.ST: Code review is a tool to help teams increase their software engineering maturity, and in the end this means delivering higher value to customers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of a code review process, but I do not understand how the code review can last only 55 minutes.

X.T: 11 Best Practices for Peer Code Review - IBM Innovate Conference 2011

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some generalities about Code Reviews (with no link with the presentation title…) and a demo of Smart Bear’s CodeCollaborator.

X.T: Six Ways to Make Your Peer Code Reviews More Effective

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some short tips for code reviews.

X.T: Code Health: Too Many Comments on Your Code Reviews?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short list of good pieces of advice.

X.T: Code Health: Understanding Code In Review

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Don't waste time reviewing code that is hard to understand, just ask for it to be clarified.

X.T: Code Health: Respectful Reviews == Useful Reviews

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short list of tips for code reviews.
Some sound advice for the code review process.

X.ST: A modern branching strategy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A proposal to differentiate code changes that need no code review, changes that can be reviewed later on, and code that must be discussed before being committed in the product.

X.T: Why Pull Requests Are a Bad Idea • Dave Farley • GOTO 2022

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why pair programming is better than code reviews.

X.T: Comment merger sa PR en 10 secondes ? Avez-vous essayé les mob code review ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: ThibautCantet proposes to perform mob code reviews. I am not convinced.

X.T: Comment booster l'onboarding dans vos équipes de développement ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some well-known facts about the challenges of onboarding and a demo of Promyze.
A long list of thoughts and pieces of advice about pair programming.

X.T: The Mortifying Ordeal of Pairing All Day
X.ST: I had to confront a lot of my fears about myself, sometimes every day. I had to learn to show someone else all the things I didn’t know, my limitations as a human and a software engineer.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Pairing most of the time is exhausting.

X.T: Mob Programming – A Whole Team Approach by Woody Zuill

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A positive testimony on mob programming.

X.T: Mob Programming : je ne développerai plus jamais seul (A. Victoor & J. Rouve)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some positive feedback on mob programming.

X.T: Mob programming : un confort de l'ancien monde ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same. Given the spelling mistakes, I presume this blog was not written by a mob.

X.ST: What's new in the GNU Compiler Collection release series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short description of the GCC4 releases.

X.T: GCC hacks in the Linux kernel
X.ST: Discover GCC extensions for the C language

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The presentation of some gcc extensions used by the Linux kernel.
Using stochastic search to optimise object code.

X.T: Debugging tools and techniques for Linux on Power

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some very basic introduction of Valgrind, gdb, jdb and strace. This can interest only persons who are discovering debugging tools on Linux.
VMware allows to record a run demonstrating a bug and to replay it exactly the same way in Visual Studio. This is a neat use of virtualisation.
Another debugger implementation enabling the record and analysis of a bug scenario. But this tool is limited to Java.

X.T: Developing Software in a Hostile Environment

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some tricks with the memory allocator to force some dormant malloc/free bugs to become apparent.

X.ST: Find and fix memory leaks in wireless applications

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A simplistic solution for finding memory leaks, it is unwieldy and supposes that you liberate all your memory blocks when exiting. But this article can be a starting point if you want to think how a real memory checker could be implemented (yes, you will have to do some highly OS dependent stuff…).

X.ST: Open source software clarifies complex call structure

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some low-level gcc hacking to create a graph call.
A description of fastBT, a table-based binary translator that can be used to instrument dynamically the code.

X.T: Testing Chromium: AddressSanitizer, a fast memory error detector.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another memory access checker.

X.T: How to improve Purify's run-time performance

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some tips and tricks to make faster Purify runs.

X.T: How does Purify find errors on the stack?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short description of the Purify stack check limitations.

X.T: Instrumenting X libraries under Solaris 2.6 and later

ARTICLE.COMMENT: For those who are unable to link (under Purify) with the X libraries because they have forgotten /usr/openwin/lib in their LD_LIBRARY_PATH.

X.T: C++ Code Analysis: an Open Architecture for the Verification of Coding Rules

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of a coding rules checker implemented with javacc.
The author states the obvious: define coding rules applicable to your domain and verify them with a static analyser.

X.T: Why You Don't Trust Your Linter • Jeroen Engels • GOTO 2022

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some opinionated comments on linters from someone who wrote one for Elm.

X.T: User Interface Challenges in Static Defect Detection

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some interesting comments on the way developers interact with static analysis tools.

X.T: Steering the Pyramids - Tools, Technology, and Process in Engineering at Microsoft

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of the tools used by Microsoft to improve the quality of their products, this is interesting to see what are their evolution and challenges.
A presentation of PMD and how to define rules in it.

X.T: FindBugs, Part 1: Improve the quality of your code

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some examples of bugs reported by FindBugs and how to integrate it in the Ant build.

X.ST: How to write custom detectors to find application-specific problems

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An example showing how to define his/her own rules.

X.T: Java theory and practice: Kill bugs dead
X.ST: Inspection tools like FindBugs provide a second layer of defense against common coding errors

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author describes how FindBugs can flag some bugs he described in previous articles.

X.T: Using Static Analysis For Software Defect Detection

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good overview of FindBugs: some examples of detected bug patterns, the results of running FindBugs on some well-known products, new features (using annotations, bug history), possible future improvements… Williams also speaks about its new project: Marmoset.

X.T: Checking System Rules Using System-Specific, Programmer-Written Compiler Extensions
Checking System Rules Using System-Specific, Programmer-Written Compiler Extensions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors describe how they created a tool with a simple language to catch some types of error in Linux, OpenBSD…

X.T: Homeland Security helps secure open-source code

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Coverity gets some money from DHS.

X.T: A Bug a Month? It's Harder Than You Think

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An interview of JimGimpel about his "Bug of the Month" ads.
A presentation of Julia and a comparison with Eclipse and NIT for nullness analysis.

X.T: Kill the Noise! to Change Gear in our Code Analyzers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Sonar team is reclassifying the rules as bugs vs. warnings.

X.T: Porter le Flambeau du Clean Code à l’ère du GenAI

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some little information about the history of code quality, the impact on AI, and an advertisement for Sonar.
Some basic non-technical information about static code analysers and Infer.

X.T: EXTRA BITS: Demonstrating How Code Checking Works - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous video.

X.T: Software Remodeling: Improving Design and Implementation Quality - Using audits, metrics and refactoring in Borland® Together® ControlCenter™

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why static code analysis and software metrics are a good complement of human code reviews and can help to drive refactoring.

X.T: In pursuit of code quality: Monitoring cyclomatic complexity
X.ST: What to do when code complexity is off the charts

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very basic introduction to cyclomatic complexity and some tools computing it. The CC computation formula is not even given.
Using some simple and language neutral metrics to analyse a code base.

X.T: Code Red: The business impact of low code quality

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A lenghty whitepaper claiming that poor code is more costly. But there are no details, just marketing ststistics bullshit.

X.T: The Three Projections of Doctor Futamura

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Ruby Conf 2013 - Compilers For Free by Tom Stuart

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of partial evaluation and, too quickly, of Futamura projections.

X.T: Compilers For Nothing, Executables For Free!

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
A too fast description of Futamura projections (the slides are herehttps://vaibhavsagar.com/presentations/partial-evaluation/#/title-slide
en
frHTML).

X.T: Interface Grammars for Modular Software Verification

ARTICLE.COMMENT: In order to simplify a system or to replace the components unavailable for analysis, stubs are used. These ones are generated by parsing a grammar modelling these components.

X.T: Digital Design: Beyond Trial and Error

ARTICLE.COMMENT: FredFurtek proposes a new methodology for performing formal verification in the case of concurrency. This one combines boolean expressions and regular expressions. The idea seems interesting, but it is realistic for real, i.e. non trivial, systems?

X.T: Creating Useful Naming Conventions: Business Considerations

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some thoughts about naming conventions.

X.T: Hunting for great names in programming

ARTICLE.COMMENT: About the pleasure to choose good names for variables, methods and classes.
Some simple but good advice for chosing identifiers.
How to handle a complex model.

X.T: Constant/Migrate/Compute: A Workflow for Partitioning Complexity

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A strategy for implementing a feature by splitting it in baby steps.

X.T: One Bite At A Time: Partitioning Complexity

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of strategies for splitting a code change into simple steps.

X.T: Complexity Partitioning and Inheritance: Two Wins and a Big Loss

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An example (using an inheritance hierarchy) where the partitioning may end up being more complex.
The word "Refactoring" should not be used for any kind of code restructuring.
WardCunningham explains how he coined the "technical debt" metaphor.

X.T: Comment lines by Kyle Brown: Paying back technical debt

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
The author suggests a five steps process to manage the technical debt:
1) Assess what you owe
2) Stop incurring new debt
3) Choose your debt reduction strategy
4) Stick with the plan!
5) Track and reassess your progress.
Take the opportunity to clean up the code while adding a feature or fixing a bug.

X.T: Use, Disuse, and Misuse of Automated Refactorings

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study of Eclipse refactoring tools: Which ones are used? Which ones are not used? Why? How can they be more accessible?
Some thoughts about refactoring: how to sell it to managers, the different types of refactoring…

X.T: RailsConf 2014 - All the Little Things by Sandi Metz

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The gilted rose kata which is a refactoring kata: the open/close principle, many small objects, refactoring requires temporary complexity increase.

X.T: Refactoring code that accesses external services
X.ST: When I write code that deals with external services, I find it valuable to separate that access code into separate objects. Here I show how I would refactor some congealed code into a common pattern of this separation.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all: a detailed example of refactoring some code calling the YouTube API.
The author explains the basic refactorings and that it is better to rely on the IDE. But my experience is that some developers blindly following IDE refactoring proposals end up writing crappy code…

X.T: The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up Code

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some non-technical rules for tidying up code.

X.T: What Refactoring Is and Is Not

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Big rewrites must not be called refactoring and they should be avoided by doing real refactoring i.e. doing continuous code cleanup under the control of a correct suite of automated tests.
Some examples of small code cleanups.

X.T: Sipping the Big Gulp: 2 Ways to Narrow an Interface

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very simplistic example of tidying up: changing a routine so it accepts an object attribute instead of the whole object can be done by creating a new routine to replace the old one or by changing the parameter of the routine.

X.T: Refactoring Java, Part 1: Driving agile development with test-driven development
X.ST: Refactoring makes your organization’s code simpler, which means fewer bugs and easier maintenance.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author tries to slowly detail the TDD process (and in particular the refactoring) but he goes too far and he starts by mixing production and test code. This will not help new comers to understand the whole process.

X.T: Refactoring Java, Part 2: Stabilizing your legacy code and technical debt
X.ST: Pin-down tests are the key to stabilizing your legacy Java code.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using the Gilded Rose kata to demonstrate writing unit tests (before refactoring) from the specification and by analysing code coverage.

X.T: Refactoring Java, Part 3: Regaining business agility by simplifying legacy code
X.ST: By making the code easier to understand, you also make it easier—and safer—to maintain.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author describes in details some refactorings (constant extraction, method extraction…). But I consider that he is wrong when using the extracted constants in his unit tests.

X.ST: What does a metaphor like “technical debt” mean? And what doesn’t it mean?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The usual description about the danger of improperly using the metaphor, the cost of the technical debt is the additional time and effort spent working on the code.

X.T: Gilding the Rose: Refactoring-Driven Development - Kevlin Henney - ACCU 2023

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed description of a gillted rose refactoring (in C#).
Some examples of improper use of null and cleaning them with IntelliJ IDEA.
A violation of the law of Demether and how to fix it.
Some examples of using a List where a Map or a Set should be used.
Simplifying some complex code by removing mutable variables.
Fixing a method that violates the Single Responsibility Principle.
Some miscellaneous ideas on how to simply code using to many ifs.
The author proposes three strategies to clean up messy code: break into smaller methods, manage one problem at a time, model the data/algorithm.
A code Kata: computing prime factors in Java using TDD.
Some advice for performing code katas.
ChongKim explains the benefits he got from practicing code katas.

BLIST.TITLE: Kent Beck’s limbo / test && commit || revert

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some thoughts about how to have a massive team of developers working on a code base.
Experimenting ideas of the previous article wit textual diffs and Git.
Pushing the experiment in a new direction: if the tests fail, the code change is reverted.

X.T: TCR (test && commit || revert). How to use? Alternative to TDD?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of TCR and a simple experiment with it.
A demonstration of the TCR process.

X.T: Trying out test commit or revert

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed try of using TCR on the Fizz Buzz kata on Node.js.
A minimalist setup for doing TCR is VS Code.
Some small feedback on TCR: it does not enforce small steps, but it works when doing these.
The author speaks about a tool to generate a tutorial from a TCR log, but there is little information here.
Learning to separate and sequence structural and behavourial changes.

X.T: Software Design is Human Relationships: Part 1 of 3, Perspective

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Introducing waiters (people waiting for system behaviour change) and changers (people who can change the behaviour).

X.T: Software Design is Human Relationships: Part 2 of 3, Waiters, Changers, and Sufficiency

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Interleave behaviour and structure changes so waiters do not get frustrated.

X.T: Software Design is Human Relationships: Part 3 of 3, Changers & Changers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Changers may disagree on how the structure should be changed or on how to order behaviour and structure changes.

X.ST: Un logiciel pas si gazeux

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some (non-technical) information about Jupyter.

X.T: Best practices for writing code comments
X.ST: While there are many resources to help programmers write better code—such as books and static analyzers—there are few for writing better comments. While it's easy to measure the quantity of comments in a program, it's hard to measure the quality, and the two are not necessarily correlated. A bad comment is worse than no comment at all. Here are some rules to help you achieve a happy medium.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic and good advice on commenting code.

X.T: Reduce technical debt by valuing comments as much as code

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some proselytising for code comments and comment driven development.

X.ST: Would going above and beyond when fixing terrible code have serious consequences?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Being afraid of having done the right thing.

X.ST: It's a situation a coder should never have to face: perpetuating bad coding practices from years ago, or just fixing the darn thing!

X.T: 700,000 lines of code, 20 years, and one developer: How Dwarf Fortress is built
X.ST: Dwarf Fortress is one of those oddball passion projects that’s broken into Internet consciousness. It’s a free game where you play either an adventurer or a fortress full of dwarves in a randomly generated fantasy world. The simulation runs deep, with new games creating multiple civilizations with histories, mythologies, and artifacts. I reached out to him to see how he’s managed a single, growing codebase over 15+ years, the perils of pathing, and debugging dead cats. Our conversation below has been edited for clarity.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An interview of TarnAdams, the developer of Dwarf Fortress.

X.T: Podcast 377: You don't need a math PhD to play Dwarf Fortress, just to code it
X.ST: I am a dwarf and I'm digging a hole.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: More information about Dwarf Fortress.
